thread.title: TomPegden commented UPDATE: Shares in Leicestershire companies rally after Leadsom...
thread.title_full: TomPegden commented UPDATE: Shares in Leicestershire companies rally after Leadsom...

author: TomPegden
title: TomPegden commented UPDATE: Shares in Leicestershire companies rally after Leadsom...
text:
Comments (1) 
Shares in Leicestershire companies rallied following the news that Andrea Leadsom had quit the Tory leadership contest - paving the way for Teresa May to become Prime Minister. 
The Stock Market took reassurance after it appeared a lengthy leadership battle - when the country is on the backfoot following the Brexit vote - may now not be needed. 
Mrs Leadsom stepped aside after failing to win enough support among Tory MPs. 
Shares in Coalville-based housebuilder Barratt Developments and brick company Ibstock rose sharply after Mrs May said housebuilding would be a priority if - and when - she becomes PM. 
Almost every company in the FTSE Top 250 rose. 
Barratt was up 8 per cent this lunchtime at £4.02, while Ibstock was up 6 per cent at £1.34. 
Enderby's Next was up 3.4 per cent at £51.10 while Syston homeware chain Dunelm rose 3.5 per cent at £8.31. 
Breedon Aggregates was up 2.9 per cent and Topps Tiles, which is headquartered in Enderby, was up 1.6 per cent. 
Prior to the leadership announcement, Barratt Developments, Next, Ibstock, Breedon Aggregates and Topps Tiles had seen millions wiped off their share prices following concerns about a drop in property demand. 
Barratt, based at Bardon, near Coalville, fell to two-year lows last week. 
It was trading at £5.20 on the day of the referendum but was down to £3.26 last Wednesday. 
Following the referendum chief executive David Thomas said the housebuilder had been prepared for the out vote and said the "strong fundamentals of the business were unchanged" - to meet demand from a lack of quality homes in the UK. 
Meanwhile, Breedon was changing hands at 68p a share on June 23, and at one point hit 54p. Shares were 62.9p today. 
Ibstock shares had been £1.99 on June 23 while Topps Tiles, of Enderby, have gone from £1.48 to £1 today. 
Share specialists said confidence in construction and the property market "soured" after the Brexit vote, although prices were not expected to be hit as badly as they were during the Credit Crunch. 
A spokesman for stockbroker AJ Bell said: "Since the EU referendum vote, the roof has fallen in on Barratt's shares – as it has across the whole housebuilding sector – and they have fallen to two-year lows amid as yet unfounded fears that a UK house price and broader economic downturn may follow the Leave vote." 
David Cheetham, market analyst and foreign exchange broker at trading company XTB.com, said while the long-term impact of Brexit on construction was uncertain, there had been "panic-selling in shares of firms within the industry". 
He said: "Not all of this sharp sell-off in price should be attributed solely to adverse trading conditions in the new post-Brexit UK as [not] until Article 50 is invoked and a Brexit actually occurs will there be any material impact on trading terms. 
"Furthermore, at least a portion of the selling seen since June 23 could be seen as an over-reaction as the markets clearly believed that the Remain camp would prevail – as evidenced by the price action in the pound before and after the result was announced. 
"Barratt Developments and Ibstock are among the worst hit since the vote, but the impact can be felt industry-wide. 
"Whilst there is little to suggest this will mark a substantial house price decline like the one seen during the 2008 financial crisis, sentiment has certainly soured and the relentless run-up in house prices over the past few years may at the very least pause until investors can ascertain with a greater degree of certainty the longer term implications for property of a Brexit." 
Mr Cheetham said an anticipated cut in the Bank of England base rate would go "some way" to alleviating fears, although the "cloud of uncertainty" remained overhead and could see house price growth checked. 
On Friday, the International Monetary Fund downgraded its projections for growth in the Euro area.
